job_title: Pathways to Sustainability: An Interdisciplinary Approach
application_procedure:
Applicants are required to apply to the Arts & Science TAship application website at: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/env/login

Applications should include: i) a letter of application, explaining why you are qualified for the course(s) to which you are applying, and ii) a CV (including academic and applied environmental experience). Please note: The letter of application should be combined with your CV, and uploaded as a single file, where you are asked to upload your CV. Applicants are requested not to apply to TA positions for which they do not have the qualifications listed under "Minimum Qualifications".
duties: Duties include delivering 3 tutorials for 10 weeks, responding to student emails, grading term tests, assignments and final exams,  and general assistance. Additional duties supported through the Writing Integrated Teaching program, which may include additional training, benchmarking sessions, and other activities, for a total of 6 hours.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolment in the School of Graduate Studies, U of T and competence in the area of the course material.
qualifications_preferred:
A University of Toronto graduate student who has demonstrated scholarly capacity in Sustainability, with interest in the topics listed in the course description. 

Course Description: Building upon ENV221H1, shows how environmental studies is working to knit different disciplinary perspectives into one interdisciplinary body of knowledge; interplay of science and values in definition and framing of issues; roles of markets, politics and ethics in developing solutions; local to global scale; historical and current timeframes.

qualifications_preferred: Completed Bachelor of Music degree preferred

job_title: Introductory Chemistry I: Structure and Bonding
application_procedure: UTSC: CUPE Hiring Application (utoronto.ca)
duties:
Candidates are expected to provide oversight to the lab environment, ensuring that all students are working safely, and providing an enhanced learning experience through direct student engagement during their laboratory experiments. Candidates will need to prepare for each experiment by reading the provided materials and attending the training sessions. During the laboratory period, candidates will walk around the lab room(s), observing students as they work and ensuring that all safety protocols are being observed. They will engage with students as they complete their experiments, offering guidance as needed to help students understand the lab procedures, techniques, and concepts.  
The candidate must be available during at least one of the following 2-hour blocks of time:  
Mondays: 2:30 PM - 4:30 PM 
Tuesdays: 9:30 AM - 11:30 AM; 2:30 PM - 4:30 PM
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A B.Sc. with a major or specialist in chemistry is required for the positions; however, senior undergraduate chemistry students at UTSC who have completed CHMB16H3 and at least one C-level CHM course with a lab may also be considered. Applicants must have excellent foundational knowledge of core chemistry principles and have strong laboratory skills, including basic techniques such as titrations, weighing by difference, solution preparation and preparing calibration curves. Candidates should demonstrate effective teaching assistance skills in a lab setting. Excellent communication and interpersonal skills are essential, as well as the ability to work collaboratively and supportively with students, teaching assistants, and faculty. Preference will be given to candidates enrolled in a Ph.D. in chemistry or related field with prior teaching experience.

job_title: Introducing Global Asia and its Histories
application_procedure: Applications should be submitted electronically, with a current curriculum vitae via https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/hcs/app/ta
duties:
Tutorial Section: TUT001 (Tuesday 3-4pm), TUT003 (Tuesday 4-5pm), TUT005 (Tuesday 5-6pm).
Teaching Assistants in this course will serve as both Tutorial Leaders and Grading Assistants. They will lead weekly in-person tutorials ; hold regular office hours and respond to students’ inquiries in person and in writing; promptly grade and offer students detailed feedback on assignments, tests and exams; invigilate exams; engage with students with diverse needs and experiences in a professional and supportive manner that improves the learning experience for all students, and to foster an interactive and collaborative classroom dynamic. Additional duties may involve course support services, such as updating course content and information on Quercus and other duties as determined by the supervisor.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolled in an MA or PhD program in Global Asian Studies, History, or a related discipline. Have solid prior knowledge and understanding of the subject matter as demonstrated through current research, previous coursework, or previous TA/GA placements in similar or related courses.
qualifications_preferred: Prior in-person experience as a TA with strong organizational skills for Asian Studies or introductory humanities courses
tutorial: Please see the latest Tutorial/Lab Schedule on the Registrar's Timetable at https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/registrar/timetable

job_title: Introductory Chemistry I: Structure and Bonding
duties: Successful applicants will: attend in-person training and weekly organizational meetings with the supervisor; supervise up to 24 students in an in-person environment; read the lab manual and relevant material to deliver a pre-lab talk for each experiment; demonstrate lab set-ups; evaluate student preparation via marking lab notebooks; grade post-lab assignments and lab exams; maintain attendance and marks records; attend benchmarking session training for marking writing assignment.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Applicant must have completed an undergraduate degree with a major or specialist in chemistry and have an excellent foundational knowledge of core chemistry principles including quantum model of the atom, modern bonding theory, and solution chemistry.  Applicant should be familiar with basic lab techniques such as titrations, weighing by difference, and preparing calibration curves. Applicant should be comfortable with using technology such as Microsoft Teams or Zoom. 

The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.

application_procedure: Applicants must submit a cover letter, curriculum vitae, and previous teaching evaluations, if applicable. Applications should be addressed to the Associate Dean, JD Program and must be submitted by email to chris.essert@utoronto.ca
duties: This posting is for an emergency course instructor for Civil Procedure, a mid-size course offered in the Faculty’s Juris Doctor program. The instructor will co-teach with other instructors and will be responsible for performing many of the duties associated with teaching a graduate course, including developing and delivering course materials, lecturing, preparing and delivering assignments and exams, marking student work and participation, providing student feedback, submitting grades to the Associate Dean, JD Program, and more. The instructor is also required to attend any faculty orientation meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Assistant or Associate Dean of the JD Program. Please note that this course will be delivered in-person. As such, the instructor will be required to regularly attend the St. George campus to teach the course and meet with students.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: This position is open to all students in the Faculty of Law’s SJD program. Prior teaching experience is strongly preferred.
qualifications_preferred: Past teaching experience is more relevant than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position. Familiarity with course content and knowledge of the Canadian legal system is also preferred. The ability to manage deadlines and proven excellent communication and collaboration skills are essential.
salery: $9,276.01 (if there is a discrepancy between the posted salary and that required by the Collective Agreement, the rate provided in the Collective Agreement shall prevail)

application_procedure: Please apply vis OISE hiring system (https://hiring.oise.utoronto.ca/).
duties: Working as a member of a team of graduate students to: • Offer one-to-one advising appointments to all OISE graduate students including teacher education students who require assistance with their oral and written communication skills in the following areas; o academic writing (planning, organizing, writing and revising academic papers such as essays, MRPs, theses, dissertations, manuscripts for publication, funding applications, lesson plans, portfolios, personal journal entries); o presentation skills (in-class presentations, conference presentations, lesson delivery); • Provide support to teacher candidates in developing teacher skills (lesson planning process, mock lesson feedback) and developing strategies to meet the diverse needs of learners; • In conjunction with the annual Professional Preparation Conference, provide support for teacher education students preparing for job applications and interviews; • Develop and offer workshops for graduate students on a number of topics related to academic skills development; • Provide individualized support for international students and new Canadians with their English language development (grammar, oral communication, listening, reading and pronunciation skills); • Support international students and new Canadians in acculturating to the university environment; • Support internationally educated teacher candidates to become familiar with the culture of Canadian K-12 schools; • Promote the services of the OISE Student Success Centre to faculty members and students; • Use the online appointment booking and tracking software to post summaries of appointments; • Attend and contribute to monthly team meetings.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Preference will be given to OISE doctoral students. This position requires a high level of proficiency in English, strong communication and writing skills, strong interpersonal skills, knowledge of second language learners as well as experience working with English language learners. Teaching experience is not mandatory but will be considered a significant asset in supporting some components of the OSSC's mandate and OISE students. Given OISE's students' class schedules, flexibility to offer appointments and workshops outside of the regular 8:30 to 4:45 office hours are required. OSSC support activities may take in person, online or both. All advisors must be able to perform online appointments using the OSSC's online system. Therefore, it is expected that advisors have technological equipment with internet capabilities.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience working in a university writing centre, must be able to work well independently and as part of a team, and create a learning environment of mutual respect and fairness that supports diversity and inclusion.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter and curriculum vitae by 11:59pm EST on December 5, 2024  to hr.innis@utoronto.ca. duties:

qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate students who have completed one year of graduate study and who have a demonstrated scholarly expertise in English literature, Academic Writing, Professional Writing, and/or Rhetoric. Some experience with teaching courses in or marking papers in professional writing and/or report writing would be an advantage. qualifications_preferred: Some experience with teaching courses in or marking papers in professional writing and/or report writing would be an advantage. Experience teaching business/commerce/management students would be an advantage.

job_title: Integrated Approaches to Research Appraisal and Utilization Part 2
application_procedure: This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies and Postdoctoral Fellows. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Visit the Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing website for instructions on how to apply for Teaching Assistant positions https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/current-students/teaching-assistantships/. The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position. The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodation at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at UofT, please visit our Accommodation webpage. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.
duties: Attend synchronous classes and in-person residency week; Meetings with supervisor; Course orientation, marking meetings and as per supervisor request; Reading text and journal articles relevant to course content and assignments; Marking, grading and providing feedback for assignments and papers (complete all grading for all student work that is completed during the term of the appointment, up to and including final assignments); Monitoring and responding to Quercus postings and email enquiries from students; Meeting and providing support with students during TA and requested hours; Attending virtual  office hours and learning events as negotiated with supervisor.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD students only; Current U of T graduate students in good standing.
qualifications_preferred: Interest in research designed and approaches.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Proficiency in propositional and first-order logic, probabilistic graphical models (Bayesian networks), basic machine learning, Markov decision processes and basic reinforcement learning, data structures (e.g., trees) and algorithms (e.g., tree search), and the ability to implement all of these methods in Java. Experience with GitHub is required. Strong communication and coaching skills, good time management, and independence are critical.
salery: $52.97 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties:
This position is responsible (with the help of other TAs) for managing all aspects of the labs in the course. This includes leading multiple weekly two-hour lab sessions, collecting and grading the lab deliverable sheets, and answering lab-related questions. For the last two weeks of the course, the TAs will provide assistance to students in completing the course project.

This role will also co-grade the midterm along with the other TAs, and co-grade the final exam with the other TAs and professor.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Significant experience with embedded programming and microcontrollers, especially Freescale or similar architectures, is mandatory. Experience teaching in an electronics laboratory setting is also mandatory - must be able to use all basic lab equipment (oscilloscope, power supply, function generator). Training material will be provided for the specific microcontroller platform being used in the course, and preparation time is included.
salery: $52.97 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure:
Apply on the Electrical and Computer Engineering on-line TA Database. Instructions and link are posted on the ECE TA web page: https://www.ece.utoronto.ca/faculty/career-opportunities/ or directly at: https://eceta2.ece.toronto.edu/. Incoming students who do not have a UTORid yet should be able to use their JOINid to log in.

 If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: Deliver weekly Tutorial sessions, assist in preparation and mark weekly class assignments, deliver term exam review session, and participate in review and marking of term exam and final project presentation for the class.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: This graduate course will review the field of Bio-photonics, and the interactions of light and biological matter. We will review basic principles as well as the instrumentation (imaging and sensing systems) that are used in this field. There are 11-12 two hour lecture sessions, a term test, and a seminar presentation by the students during the semester. Must have taken this course or equivalent in the past. Should have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course.  The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure:
Apply on the Electrical and Computer Engineering on-line TA Database: https://eceta2.ece.toronto.edu/. Incoming students who do not have a UTORid yet should be able to use their JOINid to log in. DEADLINE TO APPLY IS 11:59pm ON NOVEMBER 8, 2024.

 If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Jennifer Lee at jenk.lee@utoronto.ca.  If you have general TAship questions, please email ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: Duties may include: conducting tutorials on use of CAD tools; conducting laboratory experiments for building and measuring circuits; assisting students in the laboratory with electronic design; mentoring student teams through weekly design meetings; grading technical deliverables; and assisting the course coordinator with developing materials related to the design project itself.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Applicants must have significant experience desigining and prototyping electronic (analog and digital) circuts, especially at the board level (printed circuit boards). Applicants should be proficient but ideally very experienced using some of all of the following toold: Altium Designer, Multism, Git, DokuWiki, and Python. Familiarirty with (Virtual Instrument Software Architecture) for instrument conrol is also a major asset. Applicants should have experience using test and measurement equipment, soldering, and debugging hardware.

duties: Duties may include assisting in the building of laboratory prototypes, setting up and conducting laboratory demonstrations, and marking laboratory work, problem sets, tests and examinations.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Experience in making and building things, e.g. robotics, mechatronics, assistive technology for persons with disabilities (e.g. self-driving mobility aid), hackathon skills, Arduino, ESP32, GNU Linux command line (sed, awk, grep, bash, etc.), C, Octave, G-code, and in depth knowledge of the field of “Wearable Computing”, “Personal Technologies”, “Human Computer Interaction (HCI)," "Augmented Reality," "Mediated Reality," "eXtended Reality," Mersivity, physical metaverse, comparametric equations, photoquantigraphic imaging, lightvector spaces, anti-homomorphic imaging, application of personal imaging to the visual arts, and algebraic projective geometry.

department: Departmen for the Study of Religion
application_procedure:
Applicants should submit (1) a current curriculum vitae, (2) an outline of the course, method of evaluation, and required textbook(s), and (3) evidence of teaching ability (e.g., summarized course evaluations, letters of reference, etc.).  A description of courses is available at https://artsci.calendar.utoronto.ca/section/Religion#programs_view-block_2-5.

Applications should be addressed to Professor Srilata Raman. Please send your application as a single PDF file to religion.undergrad@utoronto.ca. Course evaluations should be sent as a separate PDF file. The subject line of the email should read Unit 1 Application: [course code].
duties: Presenting weekly lectures and classes as appropriate, grading papers and exams, meeting with students individually as they request, and handling the other pedagogical and administrative tasks ordinarily associated with an undergraduate course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD candidacy in the Department for the Study of Religion or a completed PhD in religion or a related field. Ability to addres the themes of the course to which the application is being made.
qualifications_preferred: Demonstrated teaching experience as a teaching assistant, teaching fellow, or course instructor; extensive knowledge of the subject area and/or previous experience in the course is highly desirable.

application_procedure:
All individuals interested in these positions must submit a Curriculum Vitae and the CUPE 3902 Unit 3 application form, available at https://www.linguistics.utoronto.ca/sites/www.linguistics.utoronto.ca/files/Unit-3-Application-
Form%20-%20May%202024%20-%20Fillable.pdf to lin.dept.officer@utoronto.ca AND linguistics@utoronto.ca. No paper submissions will be accepted.
duties: The duties include oral translation from English into Yoruba; evaluate whether sentences produced by students represent what a speaker of the language might say, tell short stories and transcribe these stories with students. Describe pictures and videos in Yoruba. Each session will be recorded so that students can listen to the language outside of class time.
qualifications: The candidate must meet the following qualifications: fluent and native speaker of Yoruba; have experience or skills to interact with university students; has completed post-secondary education, and with good English skills. No teaching experience is required.

The candidate must possess good communication and writing skills.  At a minimum, the candidate should be a Masters Candidate from a relevant discipline such as Geography, Forestry, Environmental Studies, and\or Environmental Science.

application_procedure: Applicants must submit a cover letter, C.V. or resume, and a list of references by Nov 29 2024. Applicant cover letters should indicate up to three PART modules they are most suited to lead. Applications should be sent via email to the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre at academicskills.utm@utoronto.ca with the subject title: PART Unit 1 Job Posting.
duties: As a Teaching Assistant for the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre’s (RGASC) Program for Accessing Research Training (PART), the TA will design and lead a select number of modules related to introductory research skills. The TA will perform the following duties: develop and instruct assigned in-person and/or online asynchronous and/or synchronous modules, mark assignments, track module attendance, and answer module-specific student inquiries. The TA will work and meet regularly with the Faculty member directing the progam and RGASC staff. Modules to be facilitated by successful applicants include Special Topics in the Humanities and one other module to be determined from: Conducting Interviews; Descriptive Statistics; Inferential Statistics; Interdisciplinary Special Topic; Lab Safety and Conduct in Labs; Leading a Focus Group; Special Topics in STEM; Special Topics in the Social Sciences; Survey Techniques; Transcribing and Qualitative Coding
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be currently enrolled as a Master or PhD graduate student in a Humanities field at the University of Toronto. Applicants should have at least two years of experience as a Teaching Assistant at the University of Toronto and demonstrate strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops (e.g., tutorials, practicals, courses, etc.). Applicants must have experience conducting qualitative and/or quantitative research at the graduate level. Applicants must have the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with PART administrators, students, and other Teaching Assistants.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to candidates with experience developing and leading PART modules and/or teaching experience in an undergraduate research methods course. Completion of a graduate-level research methods course is an asset. Experience using Quercus is also an asset.

Responsible for weekly lectures and coordination of tutorial sections. Responsible for effective use of the learning management system (Quercus) for course delivery, assignments, evaluation, discussions and course communications; responsible for supervision, coordination, support and training of the TA/SIA instructional team, including overarching responsibility for the quality of tutorial materials and instruction and grading. The primary responsibilities include guiding and monitoring students in using the UTSC On-line Pre-Calculus module resources, responding to student inquiries, moderating the discussion boards, marking students' assignments and conducting and grading the on-line final test. The TA will be responsible for holding one in-person office hour and one virtual office hour per week for the duration of the course. All other duties will be remote.

Appointment Dates: January 6 to April 30, 2025
Sessional Dates: February 3 to March 31, 2025

Application Requirements:
1. Cover Letter
2. Resume or CV
3. Transcript (unofficial copy is sufficient)
4. Contact information and names of THREE references

duties:
This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings.  Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.
 
If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach.  In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment.
 Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.

application_procedure: Those interested should email a brief cover letter and their curriculum vitae (by Word or PDF attachment) along with the names of 2 references to: Cinema Studies Institute HR (hr.csi@utoronto.ca). Please put the course code in the subject line of your email.
duties: This course examines "cult" and "exploitation" cinema. It examines the growing popularity of cult/exploitation films as an emerging cinematic subculture that valorizes disreputable or "trash" cinema. A number of sub-genres within exploitation film, including teen films, educational/instructional films, sexploitation, and Blaxploitation, will be explored. The social politics of appropriating texts through ironic reading strategies will also be considered. The Course Instructor will follow the broad outline of the syllabus that has been established for the course, using any textbooks/films that may have been ordered. Revisions and/or updates to the curriculum should be discussed with the Director. They will lecture, grade assignments, hold office hours each week, and answer queries by email or appointment.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Required: • MA • At least 3 years experience working as a teaching assistant in cinema studies courses at University level and at least 2 courses taught as primary instructor • At least 3 years marking undergraduate essays and exams in cinema studies at the University level • A strong background in cinema studies and scholarly concentration in cinema studies beyond the MA level
qualifications_preferred: Preferred, though not required: • Demonstrated substantial knowledge of film history and film theory. Research specialization and/or publications related to Cult Cinema a plus.

job_title: Supplemental Instruction in Higher Education: Peer-Facilitated Study Groups
application_procedure: Applicants should send the requested documents below to the attention of Prof. Arsalan Kahnemuyipour, Chair, Department of Language Studies, UTM via email to jobslanguagestudies.utm@utoronto.ca by the posted deadline: 1. DLS Unit 1 Job Application form (Please submit your information here: https://forms.office.com/r/94cuaqRR5T, then "print to PDF" to save a copy of the submission), 2.Cover letter (this should include a statement onthe applicant's background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications), and 3.Current academic CV.
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University credit course, including, but not restricted to, preparation and delivery of course content; out-of-class interactions with students via e-mail and regular office hours; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; and supervision of TAs/Graders (if any) as required. The instructor is expected to be fully available for the duration of the employment period. (NOTE: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.)
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrollment in a graduate degree program is required. Advanced comprehension of the subject matter as evidenced by demonstrated experience overseeing experiential learning /facilitated study groups/supervising student leaders in related supplemental instruction courses or community-based programs is required.
qualifications_preferred: Experience teaching this course, or a similar course at the university level, is preferred.

application_procedure: Please submit an application at: https://forms.office.com/r/HHmT1mV5EB. Any questions should be addressed to psy.undergrad@utoronto.ca.
duties: Includes, but not limited to, lecturing, counselling students, test/final exam invigilation, reporting final marks, and supervising course TAs.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Minimum of PhD studies at year 3 and above, or postdoctoral studies, with extensive experience and proven excellence TAing and/or teaching social psychology and/or cognitive neuroscience at the undergraduate and/or graduate level; completion of the Psychology Department teaching practicum or equivalent.  Please do not apply if you are a Masters student or under PhD 3.
qualifications_preferred: Speciality in social psychology and/or cognitive neuroscience and/or experience teaching social and/or cognitive neuroscience courses at the University of Toronto.
salery: $9,276.01 (plus vacation pay); or $10,366.55 (plus vacation pay) for first-time CIs

application_procedure:
Applicants must submit a cover letter and resume, clearly indicating any previous invigilation experience. University of Toronto student number and confirmation of registration status on ACORN is required. Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above is required.  
Applications should be addressed to the Assistant Dean, Academic, must be submitted by email to records.law@utoronto.ca.
Please note that incomplete applications will not be considered
duties:
Assistant Invigilators will distribute and collect test and examination materials, the take attendance and collect signatures, escort students to and from washroom facilities, and monitor activities within the examination room.  Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: maintaining the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental and university policies and procedures, verifying student identification, maintaining the confidentiality of student and text/exam information, monitoring test/exam time allotments, handling student concerns/problems and escalating any issues to the Assistant Registrar and/or Assistant Dean, Academic, documenting and responding to anomalous situations, gathering completed tests/exams and returning them to the JD program team.

Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled.  Assistant Invigilators will not work more than 40 hours per week, or more than 8 hours per day.  Most JD exams are written from 9:30 am to 12:30 pm for morning exams or from 2 pm to 5:00 pm for afternoon exams.   Assistant Invigilators can work from 8:30 to 1 pm or from 1 pm to 5:30 pm.  Applicants are required to be able to accommodate invigilating exams that are held according to these schedules during both the Fall examination period (from December 5 through December 17) and the Winter examination period (from April 14 through April 25).
qualifications:
Applicants must be currently registered as students pursuing a degree at the University of Toronto and must continue to be registered as students throughout the duration of the appointment (thereby maintaining their eligibility for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work).  Any status change must be communicated to the JD program immediately, so that eligibility to continue in the appointment can be determined. This is an on-campus, in-person position. Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts.  Experience invigilating tests and exams is strongly preferred.  Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion. 

Skills: Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries, ability to demonstrate integrity and professionalism while remaining calm under pressure, communication (both oral and written), initiative, interpersonal, organizations, problem solving and resourcefulness, attention to detail, situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities, understanding and the ability to apply relevant university and government policies, procedures and legislation, ability to collaborate with others and work in a team setting.
salery: $34.22 + $1/hour worked on Saturday and Sunday shifts + 4% vacation pay. Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

qualifications_minimum: APS360 is a first level machine learning/artificial intelligence software course. The course will focus on learning through implementation of machine learning systems in labs and a project. The candidate should have strong knowledge of hands-on software development of the application of deep learning techniques to specific applications. The candidate should also be knowledgeable and comfortable working with Python, Numpy, Jupyter Notebook, PyTorch and systems built on top of these. Research or practical experience building and tuning machine learning systems is ideal. Relevant experience with writing and debugging pytorch code is an asset.  Also seeking an ability to write and an ability to understand and empathize with the level of understanding of 3rd year undergraduates.

application_procedure: Application procedure:  please complete the online application form (Visit https://https://www.utm.utoronto.ca/biology/explore-employment-opportunities to access the application form) AND send a résumé and cover letter to Victoria Senatore victoria.senatore@utoronto.ca
duties: Duties may include but are not limited to one or more of the following:  attending meetings with supervisor, assistance with grading, interaction with students and other TAs on a small group and 1 to 1 basis, consulting and corresponding with students
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Min. required is a 4-year degree in Biology with appropriate background for the course to be demonstrated
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred Qualifications
include: academic qualifications, enrolment as a graduate student, previous TA experience, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty within the Department of Biology
salery: $52.97 per hour plus 4% vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry
application_procedure:
Please complete the TA Application Form: https://forms.office.com/r/nbWepEW7Ly

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugradassist.chemeng@utoronto.ca
duties: Assist course instructor with various assigned duties including but not limited to developing tutorial and assessment materials, grading assessments and corresponding with students during tutorial and electronically.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates must have a strong background in physical chemistry and thermodynamics, including topics in stoichiometry, the properties of gases, the laws of chemical thermodynamics (calculations involving internal energy, enthalpy, free energy, and entropy), phase equilibrium, chemical equilibrium, solutions, colligative properties, electrochemistry, and corrosion. Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written, oral communication, and time management skills and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should hold a bachelor’s degree in Engineering, with a degree in Chemical Engineering being preferred.
qualifications_preferred: n/a
salery: $52.97 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties: The duties of Course Instructors shall include the normal duties associated with the design and teaching of university degree credit courses or sections of courses. These include the preparation and delivery of course content, including lectures and/or seminars; creation of course ware; the development/administration of assignments, tests and examinations; the marking/grading of student work and the submission of grades to appropriate University officials in accordance with policy; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside of scheduled contact hours; and the supervision of the day-to-day work of any Sessional Instructional Assistants or Teaching Assistants assigned to the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Course Instructors are expected to be of superior teaching ability, with suitable academic and/or professional qualifications, currency and mastery of the subject matter. Successful applicants will have clearly demonstrated teaching excellence in the subject matter through previous experience teaching the course in question, or very similar courses.
qualifications_preferred: Successful applicants will typically have significant experience in applying the subject matter in a practical environment.

duties: Teaching Assistant may expect to be involved in any of the following, as requested by the course coordinator: familiarize her/him/themselves with course material; set up and manage in-person and/or on-line course delivery as required (Zoom, Quercus); provide student tutorials if needed; help mark tests and assignments; make lecture materials and tests available to students; administer course evaluation surveys; be available for student questions by e-mail; invigilate quizzes; send reminders to lecturers and students about upcoming commitments; be present on the day of lecture to setup; attend the full lecture to assist lecturer and students; maintain the course Quercus page; prepare quiz packages; contribute to marking quizzes, paper presentations and help coordinating marking; host Q&A sessions for quiz preparation, other duties as required. The course will be delivered in-person.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: MSc/ MHSc or PhD student in Life Sciences.
qualifications_preferred: Priority will be given to candidates who are LMP graduate students.  Previous experience as a TA is preferred.

job_title: Introduction to HIV/AIDS: Health, Sexuality and Gender
department: Mark S. Bonham Centre for Sexual Diversity Studies
application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter, CV, and the names and contact information of at least 2 references, as one PDF file to sexual.diversity@utoronto.ca by November 22, 2024. Applicants may also include previous teaching/course evaluations, if applicable.
duties:
•	Facilitating or delivering guest lectures as part of a teaching team
•	Creating, administering, and grading quizzes
•	responding to student enquiries
•	holding office hours to meet with students, if applicable
•	occasional meetings with supervisor
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Master’s degree in Immunology, Biomedicine, Epidemiology, or related field, with specific research expertise in HIV/AIDS.
qualifications_preferred: Research experience on the biological/biomedical aspects of HIV/AIDS, including: immunopathogenesis, current prevention and treatment regimens, historical background of the science of HIV/AIDS, the local and global sociopolitical contexts in which it has occurred both locally and globally. Experience teaching health science to interdisciplinary students from sciences, social sciences, and humanities backgrounds. Experience working with an interdisciplinary teaching team.

•	Grading assignments

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Master’s degree in Public Health, Health Studies, Sociology of Health, or related field.
qualifications_preferred: Research experience in sociology of health, or social determinants of health, specifically in relation to HIV/AIDS, including: a historical understanding of the HIV/AIDS epidemic, and the local and global sociopolitical contexts in which it has occurred. Experience teaching health studies to interdisciplinary students from sciences, social sciences, and humanities backgrounds. Experience working with an interdisciplinary teaching team.

department: Department of Applied Psychology and Human Development
application_procedure: All applications must be received by November 19, 2024. To be considered for this position, please include: 1. One-page covering letter outlining what the applicant brings to the position; 2. Current Curriculum Vitae; 3. Course Evaluations of all recent courses taught, if applicable; If you are a current/former U of T sessional and require assistance retrieving your course evaluations, please contact your department ahead of the application deadline; 4. Names of referees may also be included but are not required.Applications should be sent to: E-mail: aphdsessional.oise@utoronto.ca APHD Chair, Department of Applied Psychology & Human Development, OISE, 252 Bloor St West, Toronto, ON M5S 1V6. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact aphdsessional.oise@utoronto.ca.
duties: Instructors are required to: Teach a minimum of 36 hours. Prepare teaching resources for each class and provide relevant materials. Assess and evaluate students' work and provide a final course grade according to OISE/UT grading practices. Be available for informal meetings/communications with students as necessary.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: 1-Candidate must be working towards a doctoral degree in psychology; 2-Expertise in the content area;3-Experience and demonstrated excellence in teaching graduate courses with expertise in content area.
qualifications_preferred: 1-Preference will be given to individuals with demonstrated expertise with related course content; 2-Demonstrated scholarship in the area of the course topic; 3-Prior experience teaching flex-mode or online courses preferred.

Please label the PDF document using the following format: LastName, FirstName - CI - Course Code.  Messages in the body of the email will not be considered.  Please ONLY include your student number if you are a student. Otherwise UTORID/personnel if you are a Post-Doc. Deadline is November 19, 2024 at 11:59pm
duties: Deliver lectures in accordance with class schedule and description; supervise TAs (if applicable); evaluate student's work and assign final grades.

The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Preference given to candidates with strong academic qualifications.  Ph.D. or post-doctoral fellows are preferred. Having repeated relevant experiences teaching (or having served as a teaching assistant) especially in this course offering is a strong asset.

application_procedure:
Application instructions: Applicants must submit a cover letter and updated C.V. by e-mail to italian.admin@utoronto.ca and italian.undergrad@utoronto.ca. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact italian.admin@utoronto.ca. This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. The position above is tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments. The Departmental Hiring Policy is available in the Department office, online at https://www.italianstudies.utoronto.ca/sites/www.italianstudies.utoronto.ca/files/ITA%20Statement%20of%20Hiring%20Policy%20CUPE%203902%20Unit%201%202020.pdf, and in the CUPE Local 3902 office.   The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodations at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoftccareers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the
University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at U of T, please visit our Accommodation webpage.  The hiring criteria for Course Instructors positions are academic qualifications, the need to acquire experience, previous teaching experience and previous satisfactory employment under the provisions of this Collective Agreement. The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position. This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement.
The position(s) posted above is (are) tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments. Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies, Postdoctoral Fellows and Undergraduate Students in the University of Toronto.
duties: Duties include course preparation and delivery of course content designed for a multi-sectional course; helping in preparation of tests, assignments, and exams, in collaboration with the course coordinator and other instructors in the course, if required; administering written and oral assignments, tests, and exams according to a shared schedule across all course sections; marking and assessing written and oral assignments, tests, exams, and class participation according to shared evaluation rubrics and according to commonality of standards; calculating and submitting grades; holding  regular office hours; managing class and grades on a shared course management site; and attending course administrative meetings as required; producing one asynchronous video for all sections of the course.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Native or near native proficiency in Italian is required.  Demonstrable skills in explaining grammar concepts clearly and concisely with relevant Italian examples are required. Demonstrable skills to correct and assess students’ written and oral work. Demonstrable skills in describing and explaining Italian cultural items with relevant comparison to the North American cultural milieu are required. Some previous experience in teaching Italian language for beginners is required.
tutorial: Monday 9:00 am — 10:00 am, Wednesday 9:00 am — 10:00 am, Friday 9:00 am — 10:00 am *Please note, this course is scheduled to be delivered in person.

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://tapp.cs.toronto.edu/hash/public/postings/QSKdpsLhZUMzcNaUmJooMuU7 ; For inquiries, contact: tacoord@cs.toronto.edu
duties: Duties include meetings, office hours and grading. Meetings take place on Wednesday 12-2:30pm on campus (Jan. 15, 29; Feb. 12 and 26, Mar. 12 and 26); Office hours may be done in person or as directed by the course instructor.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: see preferred qualifications
qualifications_preferred: The Computing for Medicine is a program run by the Department of Computer Science and the Faculty of Medicine. The course is designed to introduce medical students to programming and to the applications of computing to medicine. Students will participate in a series of bootcamp-style workshops where they will learn to program in Python and in seminars with a corresponding project on the application of computing to medicine. The course culminates in submission of a project targeting prediction of clinical outcomes in real data. Qualifications include: Excellent programming skills; thorough knowledge of Python, Anaconda, GitHub, and Jupyter Notebooks. Excellence in teaching and at least 6 months of experience teaching computer science. Excellent communication skills. Experience with applying computer science in a practical setting and broad knowledge of computer science fundamentals. PhD student in CS with relevant research background preferred.

qualifications_preferred: List of Qualifications: 1. Organization Skills: You need to be able to manage yourself, your teams, and partners assigned to you effectively, and work with other TAs. 2. Communication: You communicate effectively with different types of people. This includes students to executives at our partner organizations. 3. Professional experience in a leadership capacity in a software or data engineering team in North America: This is 100% hands-on course for the students and you need to have enough technical and leadership depth and experience to lead their projects working with community partners. 4. Proactive Leadership: Given the nature of the partnership in the course, there will be unexpected and new situations to work through. You will be provided a framework for decision making and need to be able to make decisions and act with minimal supervision while leading others. 5. Previous experience as a project-based course TA (e.g., CSC301 or CSC207) is a plus.

TA duties may include marking, assisting in active-learning lectures, holding office hours, answering discussion board questions, proofreading tests or assignments, solving test or assignment problems. This course does not have tutorials or labs. 
CSC343 is being held in-person and all TAs will have a significant amount of their TA work to be done in-person between 9am and 5pm, Monday to Friday. Assignment marking may be done online, and will require participation in meetings held during business hours. 
This course also requires all TAs to be available to mark the midterm test and final exam together in-person. For the final exam, every effort will be made to schedule marking within 5-7 business days after the final exam date. There is a small chance TAs may be required to work May 1-9 if the exam is scheduled the last week of April. The exam schedule is released in March 2025.

duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.  This course also requires all TAs to be available to mark the final exam. The final exam date is determined by the Faculty of Arts and Science and the exam may be scheduled from Dec. 6-21. The exam schedule is released in November 2024. Every effort will be made to schedule and complete the exam marking within 5-7 business days after the final exam date. There is a small chance TAs may be required to complete grading January 6-8 if the exam is scheduled the last few days of the exam period. The University is closed for the holiday break between December 24, 2024-January 3, 2025.

duties: In this course, TAs will act as facilitators in discussion sections, take attendance, check student work for completeness, administer examinations, and act as record-keepers of student efforts in their respective sections. qualifications_preferred: Strong writing skills, GPA above 3.5 in coursework related to the history and theory of architecture, landscape, and design.

application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter, CV, and a list of two referees to Alexandra Bolintineanu, Digital Humanities Coordinator, at cupe1.wdw@utoronto.ca. Please put Fall DHU235 TA application in the subject line.
duties: Teaching, Tutorials, preparation, grading, consultation with supervisor & students.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: MA in a Humanities discipline. Familiarity with teaching and research in the field of digital humanities; ability to facilitate discussion; ability to mark advanced written and oral work in digital environments and to provide effective feedback to students; familiarity with basic web design, digital text encoding (e.g. TEI, HTML, CSS), digital exhibit platforms (e.g. Omeka, Neatline), digital archives, data curation and management, data visualization (e.g. Voyant, Tableau).
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience preferred, especially as a teaching assistant or instructor in WDW235H and WDW236H. Preference will be given to Ph.D. students registered in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto.
salery: $51.93 per hour, plus 4% vacation pay. Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

job_title: A Multidisciplinary Introduction to Urban Studies II: Urban Challenges and Theoretical Application
application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter and curriculum vitae by 11:59pm EST on 20 November, 2024 to hr.innis@utoronto.ca. The subject line should include the position type (TA or course instructor) and the course code. For filing purposes, we ask that applicants applying to multiple positions please send separate emails for each position you are applying to.
duties:
•Grading assignments and examinations.
•Monitoring Quercus student responses.
•Invigilation.
•Maintaining office hours.
•If the course pivots to online, monitoring the chat during synchronous online session and facilitating the discussion happening there - if the course is run online.
**Please note, the delivery method for this course is currently in person. In keeping with current circumstances, the course delivery method may change as determined by the Faculty or the College.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

qualifications_preferred: Interest and experience in community engaged learning; experience as a TA for 2nd year courses.

course_id: POL222H1, POL232H1, and other Methods Courses
appointment_size: Each tutor will provide up to eight (8) hours of tutoring per week.  Hours may increase during peak period and reduce during off-peak.
application_procedure: Applicants should submit the following: • Covering letter • Resume/CV • Application form - email undergrad.polsci@utoronto.ca to get a copy of the application form. Applications should be marked to the attention of the Undergraduate Student Coordinator, undergrad.polsci@utoronto.ca
duties: The Undergraduate Program in the Department of Political Science seeks up to five (5) Peer Tutors for the following courses: 1) POL222H1 F (LEC0101, LEC0201, LEC5101) – Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning I 2) POL232H1 S (LEC0101, LEC0201, LEC5101) – Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning II 3) Other Method Courses. Introduction to the foundations of quantitative empirical research methods, theory and research designs. Each Peer Tutor is expected to hold office hours for peer tutoring support for the undergraduate students in POL222H1 F (Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning I), POL232H1 S (Introduction to Quantitative Reasoning II), and other methods courses. Each tutor will provide up to eight (8) hours of tutoring per week. Hours may increase during peak period and reduce during off-peak. Duties of these positions shall be performed in the Department of Political Science on the St. George Campus.
qualifications: Graduate or undergraduate students with an academic background in Quantitative Methodology, in particular an advanced understanding of the course materials in POL222H1 and POL232H1.

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://forms.office.com/r/yRTeNXcx6N  For general inquiries, feel free to contact course_instructor@cs.toronto.edu
duties:
“- Delivering the lectures in-person as scheduled.
- Maintaining course administration including: course website on quercus, marking schemes, lectures, tutorials, assignments, tests, and final assessments.
- Providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, email, the course website and/or the course bulletin board.
- Preparing the breakdown of hours for TA duties in the course and supervising the TAs.
- Ensuring that tutorials and/or labs are delivered appropriately by the TAs.
- Managing the grading for the course, which is largely done by the TAs, and carrying out any grading not handled by the TAs.
- Managing the grades and submitting final course grades, including the timely completion and release of grades and feedback to students throughout the term
- Invigilating the final exam if applicable. 
- As there are other sections of the same course that term, coordinating with the other instructor(s) to maintain consistency (this includes using common assignments and a common final exam); 
- where relevant, instructors must work together to coordinate automarking of assignments.

While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course, and must get approval from these faculty members or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate on any substantial changes to the course content or assessment methods. Instructors will also be expected to consult with the department's Teaching Support group when creating the course syllabus, final exam, and test(s).
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"- BSc in computer science or related field
- completed or working towards a graduate degree in computer science or a related field preferred
- demonstrated expertise in topic area of the course
- strong organizational, interpersonal, and communication skills
- previous experience as a course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset
- demonstrated evidence of excellence in Teaching an asset
qualifications_preferred: N/A

job_title: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. 
The deadline to submit your application is September 26, 2022. For more information, you may contact: Angela Niazmand, Undergraduate and TA Administrator, Department of Statistical Sciences, University of Toronto
700 University Ave- Rm 9160- 6, Ontario Power Building, Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5, www.statistics.utoronto.ca, E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact
jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated. Duties will include any or all of the following: attending lectures, running 
tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on on-line discussion boards, participating in training 
sessions, meeting with the instructors, holding office hours, grading student homework including written reports, and 
assisting with grading of tests and exams.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior undergraduate students (third and fourth year) with strong background in statistics and exemplary communication skills may also be considered.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate student with strong background in statistics, as well as excellent communication and writing skills, and the ability to interact well with undergraduate students.
